item.title: Alleviating Canada’s Acute Shortage of Family Doctors
item.description: British Columbia announced a plan this week that will boost physicians’ incomes, but more changes may be necessary to increase nationwide access to family physicians.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: About 11 percent of Nova Scotians are without a family doctor.

item.title: What Can US Democracy Learn From Brazil?
item.description: Both nations had presidents who attacked their elections. But their responses — and the aftermaths — were much different.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro blockaded a main road in São Paulo on Tuesday, one of many such protests around Brazil after he lost the election to Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.

item.title: U.S., Allies Vow to Protect Ukraine’s Infrastructure From Russian Attacks
item.description: Top diplomats from the Group of 7 nations discussed sending more air defense equipment to Ukraine and agreed to coordinate on rebuilding its infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Andreas Rentz/Getty Images
item.media:description: Foreign ministers from G7 nations meeting at the old city hall in Muenster, Germany, on Friday.

item.title: Rebecca Godfrey, 54, Dies; Author Found Humanity in Teenage Violence
item.description: She drew praise for the precision and compassion of “Under the Bridge,” her account of the beating and murder of a 14-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.category: Under the Bridge: The True Story of the Murder of Reena Virk (Book)

item.title: Troubled Loner? Political Terrorist? Both? It’s Often Hard to Say
item.description: The attack on Nancy Pelosi’s husband has raised questions about the role of demonizing political speech in violent acts, not for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Tuesday, as she left her home where her husband, Paul, suffered an attack by David DePape.

item.title: Rodney Graham, Conceptual Artist Who Starred in His Work, Dies at 73
item.description: As both an artist and a model, he created alternative worlds where ordinary characters seemed extraordinary.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Suspect in Pelosi Attack Was in the US Illegally, Officials Say
item.description: David DePape, a Canadian, legally entered the United States in 2008. He faces several state and federal charges after the authorities say he broke into Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home and assaulted her husband.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers outside Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home in San Francisco last week.

item.title: Qatar Offered Fans Free World Cup Trips. But There Was a Catch.
item.description: Organizers are providing travel and tickets to fans of the participating teams, including dozens of Americans. But only if they promised not to criticize Qatar, and to report people who do.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Noushad Thekkayil/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Qatar will welcome fans from every corner of the world this month. Some will get special attention.

item.title: Angry Bolsonaro Supporters Protest in the Streets
item.description: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in cities across Brazil, many of them demanding that the military stop the transfer of power to President-elect Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro gathering outside the Brazilian Army’s national headquarters on Wednesday in Brasília, the capital.

item.title: Hurricane or Typhoon? How Tropical Cyclones Get Their Names.
item.description: There are variations around the world, particularly in the Western Pacific, in how countries name and measure tropical cyclones. We can explain.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Nhac Nguyen/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
item.media:description: A man walking along the beach after Typhoon Noru passed Da Nang, Vietnam, in September.

item.title: Colombia’s President Visits Venezuela, Moving Away From Isolation
item.description: Colombia’s new president met with his Venezuelan counterpart, a milestone in the move by leftist leaders in Latin America to ease the isolation of Nicolás Maduro’s government in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Gustavo Petro of Colombia with President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela on Tuesday in Caracas.

item.title: Canada Aims to Add 1.45 Million Immigrants by 2025
item.description: The policy would increase immigration one week after the country’s census agency announced that Canada had set a new milestone in immigration.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: An increasing number of Canadians are immigrants or the children of immigrants.

item.title: Martin Intensifies as Post-Tropical Storm but Poses No Threat to Land
item.description: The storm, which was moving over the central North Atlantic on Thursday, was expected to weaken over the next few days.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: CIRA/NOAA
item.media:description: Martin, which formed as a tropical storm on Tuesday, grew to hurricane strength on Wednesday. It was classified as a post-tropical storm on Thursday.

item.title: Bolsonaro Agrees to Transition, Two Days After Losing Brazil Election
item.description: Breaking his silence, President Jair Bolsonaro did not admit defeat or repeat his baseless claims about election fraud, but his administration signaled that the transfer of power would proceed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil arriving for a news conference at the Alvorada Palace along with his ministers on Tuesday in Brasilia, the capital.

item.title: Key Evidence in Report on Missing Mexican Students Cannot Be Verified, Experts Say
item.description: An international panel said it had found numerous inconsistencies in evidence presented by the government’s truth commission on the disappearance of the 43 students in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The faces of the 43 missing students have become part of the cityscape of Mexico City.

item.title: ‘Planet Killer’ Asteroid Spotted That Poses Distant Risk to Earth
item.description: The space rock had been hidden by the glare of the sun, suggesting that more large asteroids are in a solar system region difficult to study from Earth.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews
item.media:credit: CTIO/NOIRLab/NSF/AURA/D. Munizaga
item.media:description: The Dark Energy Camera at the Víctor M. Blanco 4-meter Telescope in Chile was used to aid the detection of asteroids that orbit between Earth and the sun and are otherwise difficult to spot.

item.title: Bolsonaro Is Silent After Brazil Election Defeat
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro has not yet recognized his election defeat after months of warning, without evidence, that opponents would rig the vote.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro watching in Brasília, the capital of Brazil, as the results of the presidential election were announced on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil Ejects Bolsonaro and Brings Back Leftist Former Leader Lula
item.description: Brazilians voted out their far-right leader, Jair Bolsonaro, after a single term and replaced him with former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the leftist candidate who was elected president, on the way to vote in São Bernardo do Campo, Brazil, on Sunday.

item.title: Will Bolsonaro Dispute the Results of Brazil’s Presidential Election?
item.description: He ha
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Jair Bolsonaro reacting as Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva took the lead in the election on Sunday night in Brasília.

item.title: What does Brazil’s election mean for the United States?
item.description: From the fate of the Amazon rain forest to trade, the choosing of a new Brazilian leader comes at a key moment for the country’s relations with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump with President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil in 2019. The two leaders struck a fast alliance, bonding over a common disdain of the global climate agenda and “communist threats” like Venezuela.

item.title: Bolsonaro, in Defeat, May Now Face Charges
item.description: Brazil’s president has faced investigations that have been staved off or blocked so far given his presidential immunity. But that may now change of his defeat in Sunday’s election.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro gestures to supporters in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday.

item.title: In an evangelical church, attendees pray for a Bolsonaro victory.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arréllaga for The New York Times

item.title: Polls have closed in Brazil. Here’s what happens next.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Lis Moriconi
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voting station during the presidential election runoff in Brasília on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil Election Officials Demand Answers for Police Stops of Voters
item.description: There were dozens of reports on social media on Sunday that federal highway agents were stopping vehicles and questioning people in several states across Brazil.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, André Spigariol, Laís Martins and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexandre de Moraes, a Supreme Court justice who leads Brazil’s election agency, issued an order to the Brazil’s federal highway police chief, calling on him to provide proof that his officers were not violating election rules.

item.title: Brazil’s Runoff Faces ‘Spiritual Warfare’ for Evangelical Voters
item.description: Evangelical Christians make up 30 percent of the population and are a crucial voting bloc for President Jair Bolsonaro.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evangelical Christians praying during a service in São Paulo in 2021.

item.title: Voters cast ballots amid fears and hope for Brazil’s future.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Laís Martins
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voter of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva walks his 94-year-old mother to vote during presidential elections runoff in Brasília Sunday.

item.title: The winner of the election will likely play a major role in deciding the fate of the Amazon rainforest.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: A burned section of the Amazon rainforest in Pará state, Brazil, in 2020.

item.title: Along with millions of Brazilians, Bolsonaro and Lula also headed to the polls.
item.dc:creator: Leonardo Coelho and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who is seeking to return to office, voted on Sunday in São Bernardo do Campo, São Paulo.

item.title: How Cannibalism Became a Top Issue in Brazil’s Election
item.description: An old claim by Brazil’s president that he would “eat an Indian” took mudslinging to a new level.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, then a congressman, and his son, Flávio, who filmed an interview in 2016 in which Mr. Bolsonaro said he would “eat an Indian.”

item.title: Brazil’s polls were off during the first round. Now the right wants to criminalize them.
item.dc:creator: André Spigariol and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election officials and city workers on Saturday transported electronic voting machines to be installed in voting locations around Rio de Janeiro

item.title: Expedition Finds Cameras Left by Yukon Mountaineers in 1937
item.description: Some of the cameras, from a climbing expedition 85 years ago, still had film in them. Conservators are looking to see if any images can be recovered.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Leslie Hittmeier/Teton Gravity Research
item.media:description: Griffin Post at the site of the abandoned camera cache.

item.title: How serious is the threat of a postelection coup in Brazil?
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri para The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Brazilian presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro take part in a motorcade with first lady Michelle Bolsonaro in support of her husband in Brasília on Saturday.

item.title: Once imprisoned, a former leftist president looks to make a comeback and lead Brazil again.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama para The New York Times
item.media:description: Former president and candidate Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva with supporters on Saturday in Sao Paulo.

item.title: What to know about Brazil’s pivotal election.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election officials carried out an audit of electronic voting machines at the Regional Electoral Court in São Paulo on Saturday.

item.title: Bolsonaro vs. Lula: On Election Day, Brazil confronts a momentous decision.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A voter cast a ballot on Sunday in Brasília, the capital of Brazil, on Sunday.
